thread.title: Why a second Brexit referendum has become more likely

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Why a second Brexit referendum has become more likely
text:
Why a second Brexit referendum has become more likely Top Conservative Justine Greening joined the campaign for a 'people's vote' Share Tory former Transport Secretary Justine Greening (Image: PA) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing!
Supporters of a fresh referendum on Brexit expect calls for a so-called “people’s vote” to grow, after former Education Secretary Justine Greening came out in support of the campaign.
Ms Greening, who quit Theresa May’s Cabinet in January, became the most senior Conservative so far to call for a second EU referendum.
She said Parliament is “gridlocked” over Brexit and the public should be given another vote that includes options to remain in the European Union, accept Mrs May’s proposed deal or make a “clean break” with the EU.
Sedgefield Labour MP Phil Wilson, who also backs a fresh referendum, said: “The idea of a people’s vote is gaining cross-party support.
“I think you’ve got to welcome Justine Greening’s contribution to the debate.
“In 2016 we had the vote on whether we should stay in the EU or leave, but two years later there’s no majority on how we leave. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
“So I believe it’s got to go back to the people. We have to ask whether the deal that’s agreed with Europe suits people.
“This will be the biggest decision since the second world war and we’ve got to get it right.”
In a sign of her weakened position, Prime Minister Theresa May was forced to back down in the face of pressure from Tory rebels as the Government pushed Brexit legislation through Parliament. An activist waves European Union and Union flags outside the Houses of Parliament in Westminster (Image: PA)
She agreed to accept amendments supported by arch-Eurosceptics including Jacob Rees-Mogg.
Donald Trump would not be welcome in the UK under a Labour government, says John McDonnell
The compromise was designed to avoid a rebellion by Conservatives opposed to her proposed Brexit deal.
As the mutiny within the party continued, another ministerial aide quit over the Prime Minister’s “watered down” Brexit plan.
North Cornwall MP Scott Mann resigned as parliamentary private secretary to the Treasury, saying he was not willing to “compromise” the wishes of consttuents by delivering “a watered down Brexit.”
So far, nine Conservatives have resigned from various roles in protest at the Chequers deal.
They include Brexit Secretary David Davis, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson and Brexit Minister Steve Barker.
Cabinet minister Greg Clark pleaded with Tory Eurosceptics to support the Government’s customs bill.
He urged Tory colleagues who “want to get on with Brexit” to acknowledge that the Bill was “essential” and should not be impeded. European Union and Union flags outside the Houses of Parliament in Westminster (Image: PA)
But Brexiteer Tory MP Sir Bernard Jenkin said the Chequers plan was “dead”, telling BBC Radio 4’s Today programme: “I’m afraid it is neither beloved by Remainers or Leavers.
“It’s also quite likely to be either rejected by the EU or more demands will be made upon it so it will be even less acceptable.”
With the Prime Minister under fire from all sides, the imminent summer break may provide her with a temporary respite.
The House of Commons breaks up for the summer recess on Tuesday July 24. With MPs back in their constituencies, there will be no Commons votes providing an opportunity to challenge her authority.
However, things could come to a head at the party conference in Birmingham at the beginning of October.
And, if she survives that long, Mrs May will attend a summit of European leaders on October 18 in Brussels, where she hopes the details of Brexit will be agreed.
The PM has mounted a diplomatic charm offensive over recent days to sell the plan to EU leaders like German Chancellor Angela Merkel.
But the Brussels establishment is still likely to baulk at provisions which it regards as “cherry-picking” the advantages of EU membership while dodging obligations. Like us on Facebook
